reviewText: This isn't, on the average, the type of movie I normally watch. However I found myself quickly caught up in the story of this small 1950s farming family, and the dialogue and moods feel true. Although I was a young boy years later than this movie is set, a lot had not changed and family dynamics as portrayed here were recent family history.I too had an uncle who went to find work in Chicago's factories in the early 50s. I had close relatives on small farms with outhouses and slat floors in the kitchen where crumbs were swept into the crawlspace, and fresh paint was a luxury.This movie adroitly captures all of that, along with the daily lives and small adventures of country folks who get along day by day, and somehow find a way to persevere when faced with adversity. It is told from the standpoint of a small boy for whom all of this is just life. He knows no better nor different.This is the history of countless families all over this country, and it somehow seems important to me that it not be forgotten. I thank Grisham for his look back, and having seen the abridged version that the movie must present, I'm interested to see what else the novel holds.Recommended.
summary: This will have me reading the book

reviewText: For me, this movie isn't so much about the individuals - it's about the families trying to scratch out a living in the delta area of eastern Arkansas, and what life was like for them in the early 50's.  It had an impact on their values and how they faced the troubles in their lives.  They had to stick together to survive.Trivia: the movie got my curiosity going about that old pickup truck the family had.  (For those who also wondered:  it was a '38 or '39 Ford.)The DVD:  the usual Hallmark DVD (no captions or subtitles), but it had a few more scenes than the version that was televised by the Hallmark Movie Channel.

reviewText: Having listened to this book on tape, my husband and I were delighted to see that Hallmark Hall of Fame had turned this wonderful story into a film. We were not disappointed.This story takes place in Arkansas and is set in September of 1952.  The Chandler family owns a farm. They grow cotton and hire both, Mexican migrant workers and Hill people, to pick their crop. The two groups clash when they meet on the Chandler farm.  The story is told by 10 year old Luke Chandler. Logan Lerman gave a memorable performance as Luke. The entire cast was good, and we also enjoyed Scott Glenn in the role of Luke's grandfather.John Grisham's books are always captivating, but this is my favorite. I wish that he would write more stories like this one.  It gave us a look at America in a different era when baseball was an American past time and families worked together for a common goal. It also showed the relationship between the farmers and migrant workers who shared the responsibility of harvesting the cotton.

reviewText: Logan Lerman is one of today's finest young actors, his latest film the acclaimed "Perks of Being A Wallflower".  He wasalso in 3:10 to Yuma, and very good in "The Butterfly Effect", so I took a chance and purchased this family style filmunseen.  Apparently, based on reviews of the book on which it is based, this film is very watered down, which is ratherapparent in the fact that not much of interest happens, and there doesn't seem to be any specific goal that the film isaiming for.  It doesn't leave the viewer with much reason for why painting this house is so important.  This is not LoganLerman's fault, but rather the script writer and the director, who I guess decided that since Hallmark is supposed to befamily friendly, had to remove aspects of the original story.  Since I haven't read the book, I can't be sure, but I can saythat this film failed to fully engage me, and I suspect many others will feel similarly.  Just so-so.
summary: So So Hallmark Film Has Little Drama or Focus Thematically

reviewText: This film adaptation of John Grisham's novel is...well...quieter than the other John Grisham adaptations out there.  Our main character is Luke, played by Logan Lerman, a young boy living with his farming family in rural Arkansas, where cotton is the primary crop.  As the season's migrant workers come looking for cotton-picking jobs, Luke makes new friends and enemies, all the while he is trying to figure who is suddenly painting his family's house white.  This adaptation is definitely loyal to its source material (barely anything is changed) but I wonder if this was worth adapting.  While this story was pretty interesting in its book form, it was a bit quiet and boring on the screen.  Perhaps some more things should have been changed or this wasn't an ideal story to be adapted to begin with.  Even it's most intense moments, and there are a couple, were pretty quiet.  But it was okay.  If you're an absolute John Grisham fan like me, go ahead and get it.  Enjoy.
